question: The eosinophilic intraneuronal inclusion shown in the image will be strongly immunostained with <image 1>
description: The image shows a microscopic view of tissue stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E). The tissue appears to be neural tissue, likely from the brain or spinal cord. There are several large, round cells with prominent nuclei, which are characteristic of neurons. Within these neurons, there are eosinophilic intraneuronal inclusions, which appear as dark, granular structures within the cytoplasm of the neurons. These inclusions are stained pinkish-red by the eosin dye, indicating they are eosinophilic. The surrounding tissue includes smaller, round cells with darker nuclei, likely glial cells, and a pinkish-purple matrix that represents the extracellular space and connective tissue.
